subject: Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: After the demise of the rule of letter #36 1/2 , I propose instead the following rule: Connections between letters are not allowed to cross a syllable
messageBody:
After the demise of the "rule of letter #36 1/2", I propose instead
the following rule:

Connections between letters are not allowed to cross a syllable boundary.

I think this solves the issue regarding Utter+Roe in words such as
'around', 'arise', etc. Consider 'kangaroo'. In the following, I'll
separate letters with '+' when they are connected, ',' when a
connection is optional (or not graphically possible), and ' | ' when
they are not allowed to be connected because they reside in different
syllables.

Under the rules in the QM, 'kangaroo' would be spelled:
Key,Eight,Ing,Gay,Utter,Roe,Ooze

If a writer chose to make all possible connections, it would become:
Key,Eight+Ing,Gay+Utter+Roe,Ooze

As has been pointed out, a reader can easily be tempted to
mispronounce the word when written this way. (I guess it depends on
your accent--perhaps a better example would be 'around', but I'll
stick to 'kangaroo' since it's a so-called charismatic species.)

Under this proposed rule, the spelling would be:
Key,Eight,Ing | Gay,Utter | Roe,Ooze

or, making all possible connections:
Key,Eight+Ing | Gay+Utter | Roe,Ooze

I think this rule is easy to follow for the writer, improves
readability by providing visual cues to syllable boundaries, and
maintains the flavor of the original design of the alphabet.

Ted
